title: The Shape of Water
Writer: Guillermo del Toro (screenplay by), Vanessa Taylor (screenplay by), Guillermo del Toro (story by)
plot: At a top secret research facility in the 1960s, a lonely janitor forms a unique relationship with an amphibious creature that is being held in captivity.
language: English, American Sign language, Russian, French
awards: Nominated for 13 Oscars. Another 84 wins & 244 nominations.

title: Moonlight
Writer: Barry Jenkins (screenplay by), Tarell Alvin McCraney (story by)
plot: A chronicle of the childhood, adolescence and burgeoning adulthood of a young, African-American, gay man growing up in a rough neighborhood of Miami.

title: Spotlight
Writer: Josh Singer, Tom McCarthy
plot: The true story of how the Boston Globe uncovered the massive scandal of child molestation and cover-up within the local Catholic Archdiocese, shaking the entire Catholic Church to its core.

title: Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)
Writer: Alejandro G. Iñárritu, Nicolás Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris, Armando Bo, Raymond Carver (play)
plot: A washed-up actor, who once played an iconic superhero, attempts to revive his career by writing and starring in his very own Broadway play.

title: 12 years a Slave
Writer: John Ridley (screenplay by), Solomon Northup (based on "Twelve years a Slave" by)
plot: In the antebellum United States, Solomon Northup, a free black man from upstate New York, is abducted and sold into slavery.

title: Argo
Writer: Chris Terrio (screenplay by), Tony Mendez (based on a selection from "The Master of Disguise" by), Joshuah Bearman (based on the Wired Magazine article "The Great Escape" by)
plot: Acting under the cover of a Hollywood producer scouting a location for a science fiction film, a CIA agent launches a dangerous operation to rescue six Americans in Tehran during the U.S. hostage crisis in Iran in 1979.

title: The Artist
Writer: Michel Hazanavicius
plot: A silent movie star meets a young dancer, but the arrival of talking pictures sends their careers in opposite directions.

title: The King's Speech
Writer: David Seidler (screenplay)
plot: The story of King George VI of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, his impromptu ascension to the throne and the speech therapist who helped the unsure monarch become worthy of it.

title: The Hurt Locker
Writer: Mark Boal
plot: During the Iraq War, a Sergeant recently assigned to an army bomb squad is put at odds with his squad mates due to his maverick way of handling his work.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
Writer: Simon Beaufoy (screenplay), Vikas Swarup (novel)
plot: A Mumbai teen reflects on his upbringing in the slums when he is accused of cheating on the Indian Version of "Who Wants to be a Millionaire?"

title: No country for Old Men
Writer: Joel Coen (screenplay), Ethan Coen (screenplay), Cormac McCarthy (novel)
plot: Violence and mayhem ensue after a hunter stumbles upon a drug deal gone wrong and more than two million dollars in cash near the Rio Grande.

title: The Departed
Writer: William Monahan (screenplay), Alan Mak, Felix Chong
plot: An undercover cop and a mole in the police attempt to identify each other while infiltrating an Irish gang in South Boston.

title: Crash
Writer: Paul Haggis (story), Paul Haggis (screenplay), Bobby Moresco (screenplay)
plot: Los Angeles citizens with vastly separate lives collide in interweaving stories of race, loss and redemption.

title: Million Dollar Baby
Writer: Paul Haggis (screenplay), F.X. Toole (stories)
plot: A determined woman works with a hardened boxing trainer to become a professional.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
Writer: J.R.R. Tolkien (novel), Fran Walsh (screenplay), Philippa Boyens (screenplay), Peter Jackson (screenplay)
plot: Gandalf and Aragorn lead the World of Men against Sauron's army to draw his gaze from Frodo and Sam as they approach Mount Doom with the One Ring.

title: Chicago
Writer: Bill Condon (screenplay), Bob Fosse (book), Fred Ebb (book), Maurine Dallas Watkins (play)
plot: Murderesses Velma Kelly and Roxie Hart find themselves on death row together and fight for the fame that will keep them from the gallows in 1920s Chicago.

title: A Beautiful Mind
Writer: Akiva Goldsman, Sylvia Nasar (book)
plot: After John Nash, a brilliant but asocial mathematician, accepts secret work in cryptography, his life takes a turn for the nightmarish.

title: Gladiator
Writer: David Franzoni (story), David Franzoni (screenplay), John Logan (screenplay), William Nicholson (screenplay)
plot: When a Roman General is betrayed, and his family murdered by an emperor's corrupt son, he comes to Rome as a gladiator to seek revenge.

title: American Beauty
Writer: Alan Ball
plot: A sexually frustrated suburban father has a mid-life crisis after becoming infatuated with his daughter's best friend.

title: Shakespeare in Love
Writer: Marc Norman, Tom Stoppard
plot: A young Shakespeare, out of ideas and short of cash, meets his ideal woman and is inspired to write one of his most famous plays.

title: Titanic
Writer: James Cameron
plot: A seventeen-year-old aristocrat falls in love with a kind but poor artist aboard the luxurious, ill-fated R.M.S. Titanic.

title: The English Patient
Writer: Michael Ondaatje (novel), Anthony Minghella (screenplay)
plot: At the close of WWII, a young nurse tends to a badly-burned plane crash victim. His past is shown in flashbacks, revealing an involvement in a fateful love affair.

title: Braveheart
Writer: Randall Wallace
plot: When his secret bride is executed for assaulting an English soldier who tried to rape her, Sir William Wallace begins a revolt against King Edward I of England.

title: Forrest Gump
Writer: Winston Groom (novel), Eric Roth (screenplay)
plot: The presidencies of Kennedy and Johnson, Vietnam, Watergate, and other history unfold through the perspective of an Alabama man with an IQ of 75.

title: Schindler's List
Writer: Thomas Keneally (book), Steven Zaillian (screenplay)
plot: In German-occupied Poland during World War II, Oskar Schindler gradually becomes concerned for his Jewish workforce after witnessing their persecution by the Nazi Germans.

title: Unforgiven
Writer: David Webb Peoples
plot: Retired Old West gunslinger William Munny reluctantly takes on one last job, with the help of his old partner and a young man.

title: The Silence of the Lambs
Writer: Thomas Harris (novel), Ted Tally (screenplay)
plot: A young F.B.I. cadet must receive the help of an incarcerated and manipulative cannibal killer to help catch another serial killer, a madman who skins his victims.

title: Dances with Wolves
Writer: Michael Blake (screenplay), Michael Blake (novel)
plot: Lieutenant John Dunbar, assigned to a remote western Civil War outpost, befriends wolves and Indians, making him an intolerable aberration in the military.

title: Driving Miss Daisy
Writer: Alfred Uhry (screenplay), Alfred Uhry (play)
plot: An old Jewish woman and her African-American chauffeur in the American South have a relationship that grows and improves over the years.

title: Rain Man
Writer: Barry Morrow (story), Ronald Bass (screenplay), Barry Morrow (screenplay)
plot: Selfish yuppie Charlie Babbitt's father left a fortune to his savant brother Raymond and a pittance to Charlie; they travel cross-country.

title: The Last Emperor
Writer: Mark Peploe (screenplay), Bernardo Bertolucci (screenplay), Enzo Ungari (initial screenplay collaboration)
plot: The story of the final Emperor of China.

title: Platoon
Writer: Oliver Stone
plot: A young soldier in Vietnam faces a moral crisis when confronted with the horrors of war and the duality of man.

title: Out of Africa
Writer: Karen Blixen (based upon: "Out of Africa" and other writings), Judith Thurman (book), Errol Trzebinski (book), Kurt Luedtke (screenplay)
plot: In 20th-century colonial Kenya, a Danish baroness/plantation owner has a passionate love affair with a free-spirited big-game hunter.

title: Amadeus
Writer: Peter Shaffer (original stage play), Peter Shaffer (original screenplay)
plot: The incredible story of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, told by his peer and secret rival Antonio Salieri - now confined to an insane asylum.

title: Terms of Endearment
Writer: Larry McMurtry (based on the novel by), James L. Brooks (screenplay)
plot: Follows hard-to-please Aurora looking for love, and her daughter's family problems.

title: Gandhi
Writer: John Briley
plot: Gandhi's character is fully explained as a man of nonviolence. Through his patience, he is able to drive the British out of the subcontinent. And the stubborn nature of Jinnah and his commitment towards Pakistan is portrayed.

title: Chariots of Fire
Writer: Colin Welland (original screenplay)
plot: Two British track athletes, one a determined Jew, and the other a devout Christian, compete in the 1924 Olympics.

title: Ordinary People
Writer: Judith Guest (novel), Alvin Sargent (screenplay)
plot: The accidental death of the older son of an affluent family deeply strains the relationships among the bitter mother, the good-natured father, and the guilt-ridden younger son.

title: Kramer vs. Kramer
Writer: Avery Corman (from the novel by), Robert Benton (written for the screen by)
plot: Ted Kramer's wife leaves her husband, allowing for a lost bond to be rediscovered between Ted and his son, Billy. But a heated custody battle ensues over the divorced couple's son, deepening the wounds left by the separation.

title: The Deer Hunter
Writer: Michael Cimino (story), Deric Washburn (story), Louis Garfinkle (story), Quinn K. Redeker (story), Deric Washburn (screenplay)
plot: An in-depth examination of the ways in which the U.S. Vietnam War impacts and disrupts the lives of people in a small industrial town in Pennsylvania.

title: Annie Hall
Writer: Woody Allen, Marshall Brickman
plot: Neurotic New York comedian Alvy Singer falls in love with the ditzy Annie Hall.

title: Rocky
Writer: Sylvester Stallone
plot: Rocky Balboa, a small-time boxer, gets a supremely rare chance to fight heavy-weight champion Apollo Creed in a bout in which he strives to go the distance for his self-respect.

title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
Writer: Lawrence Hauben (screenplay), Bo Goldman (screenplay), Ken Kesey (based on the novel by), Dale Wasserman (the play version: "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" by)
plot: A criminal pleads insanity after getting into trouble again and once in the mental institution rebels against the oppressive nurse and rallies up the scared patients.

title: The Godfather: Part II
Writer: Francis Ford Coppola (screenplay), Mario Puzo (screenplay), Mario Puzo (novel)
plot: The early life and career of Vito Corleone in 1920s New York City is portrayed, while his son, Michael, expands and tightens his grip on the family crime syndicate.

title: The Sting
Writer: David S. Ward
plot: Two grifters team up to pull off the ultimate con.

title: The Godfather
Writer: Mario Puzo (screenplay), Francis Ford Coppola (screenplay), Mario Puzo (novel)
plot: The aging patriarch of an organized crime dynasty transfers control of his clandestine empire to his reluctant son.

title: The French Connection
Writer: Ernest Tidyman (screenplay by), Robin Moore (based on the book by)
plot: A pair of NYC cops in the Narcotics Bureau stumble onto a drug smuggling job with a French connection.

title: Patton
Writer: Francis Ford Coppola (screen story and screenplay), Edmund H. North (screen story and screenplay), Ladislas Farago (based on factual material from Patton: Ordeal and Triumph), Omar N. Bradley (based on factual material from: A Soldier's Story)
plot: The World War II phase of the career of the controversial American general, George S. Patton.
language: English, German, French, Russian, Arabic, Italian

title: Midnight Cowboy
Writer: Waldo Salt (screenplay), James Leo Herlihy (based on the novel by)
plot: A naive hustler travels from Texas to New York to seek personal fortune but, in the process, finds himself a new friend.

title: Oliver!
Writer: Lionel Bart (book), Vernon Harris (screenplay), Charles Dickens (freely adapted from "Oliver Twist" by)
plot: Young Oliver Twist runs away from an orphanage and meets a group of boys trained to be pickpockets by an elderly mentor.

title: All About Eve
Writer: Joseph L. Mankiewicz (written for the screen by)
plot: An ingenue insinuates herself into the company of an established but aging stage actress and her circle of theater friends.

title: All Quiet on the Western Front
Writer: Erich Maria Remarque (by), Maxwell Anderson (adaptation), George Abbott (screen play), Del Andrews (adaptation), C. Gardner Sullivan (supervising story chief)
plot: A young soldier faces profound disillusionment in the soul-destroying horror of World War I.

title: All the King's Men
Writer: Steven Zaillian (screenplay), Robert Penn Warren (novel)
plot: Based on the Robert Penn Warren novel. The life of populist Southerner Willie Stark, a political creature loosely based on Governor Huey Long of Louisiana.

title: An American in Paris
Writer: Alan Jay Lerner (story by), Alan Jay Lerner (screen play by)
plot: Three friends struggle to find work in Paris. Things become more complicated when two of them fall in love with the same woman.

title: The Apartment
Writer: Billy Wilder, I.A.L. Diamond
plot: A man tries to rise in his company by letting its executives use his apartment for trysts, but complications and a romance of his own ensue.

title: Around the World in 80 Days
Writer: Jules Verne (novel), David N. Titcher (screenplay), David Benullo (screenplay), David Andrew Goldstein (screenplay)
plot: To win a bet, an eccentric British inventor beside his Chinese valet and an aspiring French artist, embarks on a trip full of adventures and dangers around the world in exactly 80 days.
language: English, Cantonese, French, German, Hindi, Turkish

title: Ben-Hur
Writer: Lew Wallace (novel), Karl Tunberg (screenplay)
plot: When a Jewish prince is betrayed and sent into slavery by a Roman friend, he regains his freedom and comes back for revenge.

title: The Best years of Our Lives
Writer: Robert E. Sherwood (screen play), MacKinlay Kantor (from a novel by)
plot: Three World War II veterans return home to small-town America to discover that they and their families have been irreparably changed.

title: The Bridge on the River Kwai
Writer: Pierre Boulle (novel), Carl Foreman (screenplay), Michael Wilson (screenplay)
plot: After settling his differences with a Japanese PoW camp commander, a British colonel co-operates to oversee his men's construction of a railway bridge for their captors - while oblivious to a plan by the Allies to destroy it.

title: The Broadway Melody
Writer: Edmund Goulding (story), Sarah Y. Mason (continuity), Norman Houston (dialogue), James Gleason (dialogue)
plot: A pair of sisters from the vaudeville circuit try to make it big time on Broadway, but matters of the heart complicate the attempt.

title: Casablanca
Writer: Julius J. Epstein (screenplay), Philip G. Epstein (screenplay), Howard Koch (screenplay), Murray Burnett (play), Joan Alison (play)
plot: In Casablanca in December 1941, a cynical American expatriate encounters a former lover, with unforeseen complications.

title: Cavalcade
Writer: Reginald Berkeley (screen play), Sonya Levien (continuity)
plot: A cavalcade of English life from New year's Eve 1899 until 1933 seen through the eyes of well-to-do Londoners Jane and Robert Marryot. Amongst events touching their family are the Boer War,...

title: Cimarron
Writer: Edna Ferber (novel), Howard Estabrook (screen version), Howard Estabrook (dialogue)
plot: A newspaper editor settles in an Oklahoma boom town with his reluctant wife at the end of the nineteenth century.

title: From Here to Eternity
Writer: Daniel Taradash (screen play), James Jones (based upon the novel by)
plot: In Hawaii in 1941, a private is cruelly punished for not boxing on his unit's team, while his captain's wife and second-in-command are falling in love.

title: Gentleman's Agreement
Writer: Laura Z. Hobson (novel), Moss Hart (screen play)
plot: A reporter pretends to be Jewish in order to cover a story on anti-Semitism, and personally discovers the true depths of bigotry and hatred.

title: Gigi
Writer: Alan Jay Lerner (screen play), Colette (based on the novella by)
plot: Weary of the conventions of Parisian society, a rich playboy and a youthful courtesan-in-training enjoy a platonic friendship, but it may not stay platonic for long.

title: Going My Way
Writer: Frank Butler (screenplay), Frank Cavett (screenplay), Leo McCarey (story)
plot: Father Charles O'Mailey, a young priest at a financially failing Church in a tough neighborhood, gains support and inspires his superior.

title: Gone with the Wind
Writer: Margaret Mitchell (story of the old south "Gone with the Wind"), Sidney Howard (screenplay)
plot: A manipulative woman and a roguish man conduct a turbulent romance during the American Civil War and Reconstruction periods.

title: Grand Hotel
Writer: Vicki Baum (by), William Absalom Drake (play)
plot: A group of very different individuals staying at a luxurious hotel in Berlin deal with each of their respective dramas.

title: The Great Ziegfeld
Writer: William Anthony McGuire (screenplay)
plot: The ups and downs of Florenz Ziegfeld Jr., famed producer of extravagant stage revues, are portrayed.

title: The Greatest Show on Earth
Writer: Fredric M. Frank (screenplay), BarrÃ© Lyndon (screenplay), Theodore St. John (screenplay), Fredric M. Frank (story), Theodore St. John (story), Frank Cavett (story)
plot: The dramatic lives of trapeze artists, a clown, and an elephant trainer are told against a background of circus spectacle.

title: Hamlet
Writer: William Shakespeare (play), Kenneth Branagh (screenplay)
plot: Hamlet, Prince of Denmark, returns home to find his father murdered and his mother remarrying the murderer, his uncle. Meanwhile, war is brewing.
awards: Nominated for 4 Oscars. Another 9 wins & 21 nominations.

title: How Green Was My Valley
Writer: Philip Dunne (screen play), Richard Llewellyn (based on the novel by)
plot: At the turn of the century in a Welsh mining village, the Morgans, he stern, she gentle, raise coal-mining sons and hope their youngest will find a better life.

title: In the Heat of the Night
Writer: Stirling Silliphant (screenplay), John Ball (based on a novel by)
plot: An African American police detective is asked to investigate a murder in a racially hostile southern town.

title: It Happened One Night
Writer: Robert Riskin (screen play), Samuel Hopkins Adams (based on the short story by)
plot: A spoiled heiress running away from her family is helped by a man who is actually a reporter in need of a story.

title: Lawrence of Arabia
Writer: T.E. Lawrence (writings), Robert Bolt (screenplay), Michael Wilson (screenplay)
plot: The story of T.E. Lawrence, the English officer who successfully united and led the diverse, often warring, Arab tribes during World War I in order to fight the Turks.

title: The Life of Emile Zola
Writer: Norman Reilly Raine (screen play), Heinz Herald (screen play), Geza Herczeg (screen play), Heinz Herald (story), Geza Herczeg (story), Matthew Josephson (source material "Zola and His Time")
plot: The biopic of the famous French muckraking writer and his involvement in fighting the injustice of the Dreyfuss Affair.

title: The Lost Weekend
Writer: Charles R. Jackson (from the novel by), Charles Brackett (screen play), Billy Wilder (screen play)
plot: The desperate life of a chronic alcoholic is followed through a four-day drinking bout.

title: A Man for All Seasons
Writer: Robert Bolt (from the play by), Robert Bolt (screenplay)
plot: The story of Thomas More, who stood up to King Henry VIII when the King rejected the Roman Catholic Church to obtain a divorce and remarriage.

title: Marty
Writer: Paddy Chayefsky (story), Paddy Chayefsky (screenplay)
plot: A middle-aged butcher and a school teacher who have given up on the idea of love meet at a dance and fall for each other.

title: Mrs. Miniver
Writer: Arthur Wimperis (screenplay), George Froeschel (screenplay), James Hilton (screenplay), Claudine West (screenplay), Jan Struther (based on the book by)
plot: A British family struggles to survive the first months of World War II.

title: Mutiny on the Bounty
Writer: Talbot Jennings (screenplay), Jules Furthman (screenplay), Carey Wilson (screenplay), Charles Nordhoff (book), James Norman Hall (book), Margaret Booth
plot: A tyrannical ship captain decides to exact revenge on his abused crew after they form a mutiny against him, but the sailor he targets had no hand in it.

title: My Fair Lady
Writer: Alan Jay Lerner (book), George Bernard Shaw (from a play by), Alan Jay Lerner (screenplay)
plot: A misogynistic and snobbish phonetics professor agrees to a wager that he can take a flower girl and make her presentable in high society.

title: On the Waterfront
Writer: Budd Schulberg (screenplay), Budd Schulberg (based upon an original story by), Malcolm Johnson (suggested by articles by)
plot: An ex-prize fighter turned longshoreman struggles to stand up to his corrupt union bosses.

title: Rebecca
Writer: Daphne Du Maurier (celebrated novel), Robert E. Sherwood (screen play), Joan Harrison (screen play), Philip MacDonald (adaptation), Michael Hogan (adaptation)
plot: A self-conscious bride is tormented by the memory of her husband's dead first wife.

title: The Sound of Music
Writer: George Hurdalek (with the partial use of ideas by), Howard Lindsay (from the stage musical book by), Russel Crouse (from the stage musical book by), Ernest Lehman (screenplay)
plot: A woman leaves an Austrian convent to become a governess to the children of a Naval officer widower.

title: Tom Jones
Writer: John Osborne (screenplay), Henry Fielding (based on the novel by)
plot: The romantic and chivalrous adventures of adopted bastard Tom Jones in 18th century England.

title: West Side Story
Writer: Ernest Lehman (screenplay), Arthur Laurents (book), Jerome Robbins (play)
plot: Two youngsters from rival New York City gangs fall in love, but tensions between their respective friends build toward tragedy.

title: Wings
Writer: John Monk Saunders (story), Hope Loring (screenplay), Louis D. Lighton (screenplay), Julian Johnson (titles)
plot: Two young men, one rich, one middle class, who are in love with the same woman, become fighter pilots in World War I.

title: You Can't Take It with You
Writer: Robert Riskin (screen play), George S. Kaufman (based upon the play by), Moss Hart (based upon the play by)
plot: A man from a family of rich snobs becomes engaged to a woman from a good-natured but decidedly eccentric family.
